p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the seventh report of the Petitions Committee for the 47th Parliament.
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP
Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP
Ms Alison Byrnes MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP
Ms Tracy Roberts MP
Ms Meryl Swanson MP

span.span: summarising the petitions and Ministerial responses being presented.
The committee met in private session in the 47th Parliament on 8 February 2023, 15 February 2023 and 8 March 2023.
1. The committee resolved to present the following 18 petitions in accor

p.span: From 407 petitioners—requesting that Trove is kept as a free and open service to all Australians (EN4755)
From 5 petitioners—requesting the temporary postponement of implementation of revised pet import regulations (EN4756)
From 12 petitioners—requesting the electrification of Australia's freight lines (EN4759)
From 489 petitioners—requesting that Trove be fully funded (EN4761)
From 14 petitioners—requesting military support for Ukraine (EN4763)
From 17 petitioners—requesting the appointment of independent board members to Screen Australia (EN4764)
From 3 petitioners—requesting removal of requirements on student and work visas (EN4765)
From 39 petitioners—requesting to change the national anthem to We Are Australian (EN4766)
From 36 petitioners—requesting parliamentary debate prior to the indigenous voice-to-parliament referendum (EN4769)
From 8 petitioners—requesting that people are allowed to donate money to the Commonwealth of Australia (EN4772)
From 26 petitioners—requesting a change of Australia Day to the last Friday of January (EN4773)
From 69 petitioners—requesting a ban on companies who have convictions for illegal research (EN4775)
From 83 petitioners—requesting a freeze on land and businesses being bought by foreign entities (EN4776)
From 68 petitioners—requesting a ban on the sale of energy drinks to children (EN4778)
From 182 petitioners—requesting a change to the 491 visa (EN4780)
From 47 petitioners—requesting cancellation of the cashless debit card (EN4783)
From 5506 petitioners—requesting permanent residency for those who came by boat 2012-2014 (EN4784)
From 2897 petitioners—requesting continuing funding for "sealing the hills" project (EN4785)

span.span: ponses to petitions were received by the Committee on 8 March 2023:

p.span: From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition requesting Australians overseas to be allowed their constitutional right to return to Australia (EN2343)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition requesting the return of stranded citizens (EN2645)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition requesting to stop criminalisation of Australians seeking to return from India (EN2648)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition requesting to bring stranded Australians home (EN2653)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition requesting to repatriate Australians in India back to their home (EN2664)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition requesting help reunite Australian families (EN2867)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition requesting assistance to vaccinate Australians in Vietnam (EN2956)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition requesting to bring home stranded Australians (EN2960)
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care to a petition requesting help for Australia to mask up (EN3001)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition requesting to bring vulnerable Australian citizens home from Indonesia (EN3014)
From the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs to a petition regarding Rohullah Hussaini's Afghan family (EN3265)
From the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs to a petition requesting the Murugappan family to return home to Biloela (EN3462)
From the Minister for Communications to a petition requesting to ban gambling advertising in media (EN3559)
From the Minister for Communications to a petition regarding pictures of children in the news media (EN3767)
From the Minister for Government Services to a petition regarding a Royal Commission for gaslighting victims working for Services Australia (EN3925)
From the Minister for Social Services to a petition requesting new legislation regarding cost of living for Centrelink payments (EN3957)
From the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs to a petition regarding PR visas for parents (EN3960)
From the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs to a petition requesting the cancellation of visas for Russian Duma members (EN4031)
From the Minister for Communications to a petition requesting to ban the use of all sirens by radio advertisements (EN4036)
From the Minister for Communications to a petition requesting the release of FM licences in the Ballarat LAP (EN4049)
From the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs to a petition regarding the lack of a functioning computer system at the Melbourne Immigration Transit Accommodation (EN4186)
From the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs to a petition regarding smoking within the MITA compound and buildings (EN4187)
Regarding regulation of the sale of helium and releasing of helium filled balloons (EN4351)
From the Minister for Defence to a petition requesting to name the new class of Australian Submarines Rainbow Warriors (EN4515)
From the Attorney-General to a petition requesting to hold the IRGC accountable for the death of Mahsa-Amini (EN4540)
From the Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury to a petition regarding the mandated use of USB-C charging ports by manufacturers (EN4545)
From the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to a petition regarding reductions to the DFRDB scheme (EN4548)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition requesting urgent action towards the Islamic Republic of Iran (EN4571)
From the Minister for Social Services regarding an income test exemption for Disability Support Pension recipients due to vaccine injury (EN4578)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition regarding human rights violations in Pakistan (EN4621)
PETITIONS
Presentation
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 18 petitions:
National Library of Australia: Trove
It has come to our attention that the funding of Trove has of late come under scrutiny with the possibility that the Trove service may be forever disbanded.

Since its inception, Trove has become a national institution and an invaluable resource to those of us in the study of Australian History. It is a resource of which many of us have come to depend upon as a free and open service.

We therefore ask the House to guarantee suitable and specific funding and the maintenance of that funding to keep Trove free and accessible into perpetuity to all Australians as the invaluable resource it has become.
from 407 citizens (Petition No. EN4755)
Biosecurity

The Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (The Department), released revised requirements for the importation of Dogs and Cats into Australia on 12-Jan-23, with a planned implementation date of 01-Mar-23 for these new requirements.

In the rush to implement these new procedures the Department has left many pet importers in a difficult position both logistically and financially due to the unplanned and rushed nature of this proposed implementation.

The Departments new requirements also require that foreign governments shall provide an identification report for pets entering Australia. In a response to the Department's November draft report the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) made a submission stating that they do not have the manpower to perform this task, thus further disadvantaging importers bring pets from North America.
We therefore ask the House to direct the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (DAAF) to;

1. Pause the implementation of the revised import requirements for domesticated animals (dogs/cats) until such time as the Department can prove that they have the mechanisms in place from foreign governments to properly and timely support the identification of pets.

2. Recognise all existing Post Entry Quarantine (PEQ) bookings made under the previous incumbent import conditions at the time import permits were issued, and that these importers may continue the import process of their pet under the those regulations, including but not limited to the duration of the validity of the RNATT testing window of 24 months, and the incumbent 10 days PEQ stay for all pets entering Australia.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN4756)
Climate Change: Rail Transport Infrastructure

While rail freight is a vital part of Australia's economy and takes trucks off our roads, we still overwhelmingly rely on diesel locomotives for freight, which are noisy, emit potentially hazardous fumes and contribute to our national emissions. By electrifying our freight lines, we can tap into Australia's ever expanding supply of renewable energy, use less noisy electric locomotives, and move freight with zero emissions.
We therefore ask the House to investigate electrifying Australia's freight lines and to provide funding for this electrification.
from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN4759)
National Library of Australia: Trove

Trove is a database owned and run by the National Library that is filled with archives, images, newspapers, official documents, archived websites, manuscripts and other types of data. Trove is used by accessed by about 22 million people per year, which is about 60 000 a day. These 22 million people include researchers, family historians, students, historians, the curious and more.

A large part of its use is because it's free and easily accessible. This accessibility is of incredible value since many don't have the means to get this information any other way, from there being financial reasons to not being able to get this information in person to not being able to find it at all. But this may all come to an end, in July 2023 to be exact—this is when Troves funding is set to run out unless something is done.
We therefore ask the House to fully fund Trove
from 489 citizens (Petition No. EN4761)
Ukraine
Australia can not sit idly by as war rages in Europe, as innocent people and children die from indiscriminate Russian artillery strikes, torture or cold blooded murder.
We can offer more, and we should. They need more Bushmasters, we can give them more. They need training, we can offer them training from as of the best armed forces in world.

Our allies are doing much more for those in Ukraine, if there was any chance to cement ourselves as a global power, this is it and we should be giving as much as we could without compromising our own security.

We therefore ask the House to significantly increase production of military vehicles such as bushmasters, ammunition and weaponry made in Australia to support Ukraine and in return gain reputation of a significant global power.
from 14 citizens (Petition No. EN4763)
Screen and Visual Arts Industry
Screen Australia and the other screens don't support independent film makers.and give money to foreign companies.and board members projects

We therefore ask the House to investigate screen Australia and other screens on why they don't support independent film makers and why the board members get priority for their films and production and their connection to films being made . Independent board members should be appointed to make it fair. Because the application system supports foreign companies more than independent film makers.
from 17 citizens (Petition No. EN4764)
Migration
Please we are requesting to parliament members So many students and work visas want remove this 48 section and they can start new life
We therefore ask the House to remove section 48
from three citizens (Petition No. EN4765)
Australian National Anthem
This is both due to the disconnection of the Australian people from the current national anthem and the first verse of We Are Australian recognising the First Nations people.
We therefore ask the House to change the National Anthem to We Are Australian.
from 39 citizens (Petition No. EN4766)

subdebateinfo.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice

p.span: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice

Prime Minister Albanese is trashing Australia's democracy by refusing to table a Bill for the "indigenous voice-to-parliament" referendum. Despite repeated calls to provide voters with specifics to debate and a model to consider, he keeps dismissing their requests by asserting this should be a conscience-vote rather than a serious issue to consider based upon how it might affect society. In short, he expects voters to provide parliament with a blank cheque to amend the Constitution so he can enjoy the benefits of lawmaking in a climate where citizens have no right of recourse, and criticism by the Opposition can be deflected by claiming voters gave him that mandate. However, as the community is concerned this policy could institute division, it is reckless to hold a referendum before the Bill has been debated because members-of-parliament need to incorporate the community's ideas to avoid designing anything which is foreseeably at odds with fostering a more inclusive-society. Therefore, instead of assuming parliament knows better than the collective-wisdom of all voters, we demand Prime Minister Albanese consults the public then tables a Bill which details every facet of his proposal; especially: (1) the exact words to be inserted into the Constitution; (2) the precise model for the "indigenous voice-to-parliament"; and (3) which aspects can be changed later without involving voters.

We therefore ask the House to restore representative-democracy by consulting the public then tabling a Bill which provides voters with specifics to debate and a model to consider prior to the "indigenous voice-to-parliament" referendum.
from 36 citizens (Petition No. EN4769)
Australian Consolidated Revenue Fund
People may want to contribute financially to the Commonwealth of Australia (over and above their taxes) for various reasons, such as:
Because they feel that they received more than they rightly deserve in government benefits; or
because they believe that some benefits they received are not morally justified; or
because they feel guilty about something and want to make up for it; or
because they are concerned over the dire financial situation of the Australian government, already about a trillion dollars in debt; or Just because they care.

There is presently no legal way to voluntarily donate money to the Commonwealth of Australia ("legal" here means, as opposed for example to the illegal method of fabricating excess income in one's tax-return).
We therefore ask the House to introduce one or more legal methods by which individuals can voluntarily donate money directly to the Commonwealth of Australia, whatever be their reason(s).
The implementation could be as simple as publishing a government-owned bank account into which anyone can transfer sums of money, or it could be done via the ATO using an online form.
The donated income could be designated toward general revenue, toward debt-return or toward specific ministries.
Donations could be anonymous, identifiable, or both.
So long as a solution is found, we leave the above details—implementation, designation and anonymity, for the honourable parliament to consider and decide on.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN4772)
Australia Day
59% of Australians are full time employees and are subject to an inconvenient mid week Public Holiday when Australia Day (26th of January) is on a Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday.

If the date of Australia Day is to be changed, since it is a recreational Public Holiday rather than a rememberance or religious holiday, instead of a fixed date can the day be on the last Friday of January instead.
Returning to work on a Friday (or any midweek Public Holiday) is quite troublesome.
We therefore ask the House to make Australia Day be on the last Friday of January each year rather than a fixed date.
from 26 citizens (Petition No. EN4773)
Health Care

Projectveritas.com caught Pfizer's Jordan Trishton Walker (who's in charge of Pfizer's R&D, strategic op's & mRNA scientific planning division), admitting on camera, Pfizer willingly create diseases & sell you the cure. This is called illegal Gain of Function research.
As Covid-19 has already demonstrated, this reckless research is very deadly & has the ability to kill humanity.
We therefore ask the House to
Ban companies who are convicted for carrying out illegal Gain of Function research, (whether here in Australia, or in an overseas court), from operating or selling their products into Australia.
from 69 citizens (Petition No. EN4775)
Foreign Investment

We are in a time of crisis unlike anything our country has seen. As you are well aware, the Australian economy is in a precarious position, with an unprecedented number of businesses and individuals facing financial hardship & ruin.

Even in good times, it is no secret that foreign entities have been buying up Australian businesses, real estate and farmland. And now, no matter how well this crisis is handled, many businesses and properties will surely be sold off over the coming months, and logic dictates that they will be snapped up by the same groups that have been purchasing what many Australians already call too much of our country.

If this is allowed, it will lead surely devastate our economy as profits, rent, produce and manufactured goods are funneled overseas, leading to a catastrophic chain reaction as the profits of these foreign owned interests are used to drive more out of business so as to be snapped up in turn.
We therefore ask the House to put a freeze on all purchases of Australian land & businesses by foreign interests.

Perhaps a system of temporary government buybacks could fill the void, allowing people to sell to the Australian government for it to be sold back to the public in better times, but the most important point is this;
Foreign interests must NOT be permitted to buy our country out from under us while we are at our most vulnerable.
from 83 citizens (Petition No. EN4776)
Health Care

Energy drinks have become increasingly popular among young people, but their consumption can have serious negative effects on the health of underage individuals. Retail outlets such as service stations & supermarkets that sell energy drinks to kids are contributing to this problem by making these products easily accessible to a population that is not yet fully developed and may not understand the risks associated with consuming them.

Energy drinks contain high levels of caffeine and sugar, which can lead to a range of health issues such as obesity, diabetes, and heart disease. They can also cause jitteriness, anxiety, and insomnia. Furthermore, energy drinks can also increase blood pressure and heart rate, which can be especially dangerous for young people who are still developing and may be more susceptible to these negative effects.

Additionally, drinking energy drinks can also lead to dehydration, as the high caffeine content can act as a diuretic, which can lead to headaches and fatigue. Energy drinks can also cause addiction and some individuals may consume them in excessive amounts, which can lead to serious health problems.

In conclusion, these places that sell energy drinks to underage kids are contributing to a serious health problem. These products are not suitable for young people and can cause serious negative effects on their health. It is important for these retailers to take responsibility for their actions and refrain from selling energy drinks to kids.
We therefore ask the House to Make stockists of energy drinks refuse sale to children under 16.
from 68 citizens (Petition No. EN4778)
Migration

This 491 pathway was introduced as a priority pathway for migration who wants to migrate to Australia. And many international students and overseas applicants made their sacrifices leaving their well paid jobs and leaving their luxury life living in major cities like Sydney and Melbourne and moved in to regional areas in trying to secure their permanent residency.

While many migrants made all these sacrifices, on the other hand now the Department of Immigration is prioritising 189 and 190 permanent VISA applications. The migrants 491 visa processing time is much longer, and again have to complete a 3 more of living regional and gross income requirement of 53,900 to secure their permanent residency, how can this be fair.

The processing time for 491 Applications has gone up to 30 months, so basically move to regional spend a 2 years fulfil the state nomination requirement, and get the nomination and apply for the VISA and wait another 2.5 years for the VISA grant, and once the VISA is granted spend 3 more years in the regional area to fulfil the federal requirement for permanent residency, and then apply for the permanent residency and wait more years. How can this be fair, it will accumulate more than 8 to 10 years before the person gets the permanent residency, and also buy first house.
More details and signatures here as-well—https://chng.it/CqbwXSfnTq
Thank-you
We therefore ask the House to change 491 VISA application in to full permanent residency VISA, we need fair system for all.
from 182 citizens (Petition No. EN4780)
Pensions and Benefits

Serious damage has been done to citizens of Ceduna and other areas by the cancellation of the Cashless Debit Card. Immediately that the card was ceased some people have suffered due to public brawls and anti-social behaviour, excessive gambling, drug use and so on. As a consequence women and children are suffering due to money being spent on drugs, gaming and alcohol rather than on clothing, food, education and so on Levels of family and general violence. Communities are suffering because of the stoppage of the card.
We therefore ask the House to request that the Cashless Debit Card be re-instated for the general community good.
from 47 citizens (Petition No. EN4783)
Asylum Seekers
Between 2012-2014 many thousands of people seeking asylum arrived at Christmas Island and other places by boat. Some were taken to the mainland but others were exiled to Nauru or to Manus Island.

As of January 2023, over 100 still languish on Nauru or in PNG. Thousands remain trapped in Community Detention within Australia, or on the merry-go-round of repeating bridging visas, or for the more fortunate, TPV or SHEVs.

The resettlements in US or Canada have been a slow drip, not even a trickle. Many years have passed, far too many. Hundreds have given up hope of resettlement, having established friendships here and feeling settled here although denied further education for themselves or their children who have grown up here speaking Australian English. The delay has caused despair, poverty, broken marriages, frustration and incredible boredom for those who are denied the dignity of work opportunities.
Many consider themselves as political hostages of the tired and obsolete "Stop the Boats" mantra.
Australia's international reputation has suffered because of these injustices.
We therefore ask the House to , in respect of this group of people, firstly, immediately bring all those remaining in PNG and Nauru to Australia.

Secondly, grant all those—from the "legacy caseload", those on Bridging Visas, those in Community Detention, and those yet to be released from Immigration Detention Centres—permanent residence in Australia by 31 March 2023.
from 5,506 citizens (Petition No. EN4784)
Victoria: Roads
The recent Federal Budget stripped funding from the "Sealing the Hills" and "Roads for the community" projects.

Critical for the community, these significant infrastructure initiatives cover both Cardinia and Yarra Ranges Shire and will impact hundreds of kilometres of unsealed and unsafe roads, and thousands of residents.
Originally announced by the Liberal Government in 2019, this $300million project had bipartisanship support.
This project is already well underway, extensive consultation has occurred involving landowners, residents, and ratepayers.
Construction has started with designs in progress for more than half of the roads in the overall program.
Special charge schemes have been activated to coordinate co-investment delivery.
This project will improve safety and access for our residents, and importantly our emergency services. Narrow, corrugated roads with limited turning facilities limit the extent of safe access.
We are one of the state's highest risk bushfire regions.
We have been severely impacted by major storms, the storm of June 9, 2021, was the biggest on record.
Complicating matters further is a dangerous network of unsealed roadways.
The decision to strip funding from these initiatives was made without consultation with the community or Councils.
Removing this funding from the "Sealing the Hills" project will have a huge impact on the morale and the improvement in quality of life and wellbeing for residents across both municipalities.
Without this funding, the project cannot be completed.
We therefore ask the House to urgently reconsider any decision made by the Albanese Labor Government to discontinue funding for these imperative initiatives.
from 2,897 citizens (Petition No. EN4785)
PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 30 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
COVID 19: International Travel
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for the referral of petition EN2343 of 22 March 2021 requesting the government provide a plan to bring Australian citizens home during the pandemic.

The Albanese Government remains critical of the decisions made by the former government that caused so many Australians to be left stranded in precarious circumstances. Our view was that the former government should have done more to assist Australians overseas to return home.

A Senate Select Committee on Australia's response to the COVID-19 crisis found that the former government failed to establish stand-alone quarantine facilities, which resulted in overseas caps being imposed and restrictions on the number of Australians and permanent residents that could return home.
Since the 2022 election, all COVID-19 travel and border restrictions have been lifted, allowing Australian citizens, permanent residents and visa holders to travel to Australia unrestricted.
The Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) completed several audits on Australia's response to COVID-19 including in relation to the return of overseas Australias.

Commonwealth agencies are implementing recommendations in response to the ANAO's COVID-19 audit program. DFAT's implementation of agreed recommendations will improve its crisis management framework and support data management processes to better assist Australians affected by crises overseas.

Australians seeking up-to-date travel advice on COVID-19 requirements overseas can refer to DFAT's Smartraveller website to access destination-specific information: https://www.smartraveller.gov.au/global-covid-19-health-advisory
I trust this information has been of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong(Petition No. EN2343)
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for the referral of petition EN2645 of 21 June 2021 requesting special flights for Australians to return during the pandemic.

The Albanese Government remains critical of the decisions made by the former government that caused so many Australians to be left stranded in precarious circumstances. Our view was that the former government should have done more to assist Australians overseas to return home.

A Senate Select Committee on Australia's response to the COVID-19 crisis found that the former government failed to establish stand-alone quarantine facilities, which resulted in overseas caps being imposed and restrictions on the number of Australians and permanent residents that could return home.
Since the 2022 election, all COVID-19 travel and border restrictions have been lifted, allowing Australian citizens, permanent residents and visa holders to travel to Australia unrestricted.
The Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) completed several audits on Australia's response to COVID-19 including in relation to the return of overseas Australias.

Commonwealth agencies are implementing recommendations in response to the ANAO's COVID-19 audit program. DFAT's implementation of agreed recommendations will improve its crisis management framework and support data management processes to better assist Australians affected by crises overseas.

Australians seeking up-to-date travel advice on COVID-19 requirements overseas can refer to DFAT's Smartraveller website to access destination-specific information: https://www.smartraveller.gov.au/global-covid-19-health-advisory
I trust this information has been of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong(Petition No. EN2645)
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for the referral of petition EN2648 of 21 June 2021 requesting repatriation from India of Australian citizens during the pandemic.

The Albanese Government remains critical of the decisions made by the former government that caused so many Australians to be left stranded in precarious circumstances. Our view was that the former government should have done more to assist Australians overseas to return home.

A Senate Select Committee on Australia's response to the COVID-19 crisis found that the former government failed to establish stand-alone quarantine facilities, which resulted in overseas caps being imposed and restrictions on the number of Australians and permanent residents that could return home.

In particular, I recognise how distressing it must have been for Australians stranded in India when the former government implemented a temporary two week pause on direct passenger flights between India and Australia in May 2021.
Since the 2022 election, all COVID-19 travel and border restrictions have been lifted, allowing Australian citizens, permanent residents and visa holders to travel to Australia unrestricted.

The Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) completed several audits on Australia's response to COVID-19 including in relation to the return of overseas Australias. Commonwealth agencies are implementing recommendations in response to the ANAO's COVID-19 audit program. DFAT's implementation of agreed recommendations will improve its crisis management framework and support data management processes to better assist Australians affected by crises overseas.

Australians seeking up-to-date travel advice on COVID-19 requirements overseas can refer to DFAT's Smartraveller website to access destination-specific information: https://www.smartraveller.gov.au/global-covid-19-health-advisory
I trust this information has been of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong(Petition No. EN2648)
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for the referral of petition EN2653 of 21 June 2021 requesting repatriation of Australian citizens during the pandemic, including from India.

The Albanese Government remains critical of the decisions made by the former government that caused so many Australians to be left stranded in precarious circumstances. Our view was that the former government should have done more to assist Australians overseas to return home.

Since the 2022 election, all COVID-19 travel and border restrictions have been lifted, allowing Australian citizens, permanent residents and visa holders to travel to Australia unrestricted.

I trust this information has been of assistance.

from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong(Petition No. EN2664)
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for the referral of petition EN2867 of 21 June 2021 requesting repatriation of Australian citizens during the pandemic.

The Albanese Government remains critical of the decisions made by the former government that caused so many Australians to be left stranded in precarious circumstances. Our view was that the former government should have done more to assist Australians overseas to return home.

A Senate Select Committee on Australia's response to the COVID-19 crisis found that the former government failed to establish stand-alone quarantine facilities, which resulted in overseas caps being imposed and restrictions on the number of Australians and permanent residents that could return home.
Since the 2022 election, all COVID-19 travel and border restrictions have been lifted, allowing Australian citizens, permanent residents and visa holders to travel to Australia unrestricted.

I trust this information has been of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong(Petition No. EN2687)
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for the referral of petition EN2956 of 19 October 2021 requesting access to vaccines overseas for Australians in Vietnam.

The Albanese Government remains critical of the decisions made by the former government that caused so many Australians to be left stranded in precarious circumstances. Our view was that the former government should have done more to assist Australians overseas to return home.

A Senate Select Committee on Australia's response to the COVID-19 crisis found that the former government's response was characterised by poor preparation, a refusal to take responsibility and a failure to learn lessons as the pandemic progressed.
Since the 2022 election, all COVID-19 travel and border restrictions have been lifted, allowing Australian citizens, permanent residents and visa holders to travel to Australia unrestricted.

The Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) completed several audits on Australia's response to COVID-19 including in relation to the return of overseas Australias. Commonwealth agencies are implementing recommendations in response to the ANAO's COVID-19 audit program. DFAT's implementation of agreed recommendations will improve its crisis management framework and support data management processes to better assist Australians affected by crises overseas.

Australians seeking up-to-date travel advice on COVID-19 requirements overseas can refer to DFAT's Smartraveller website to access destination-specific information: https://www.smartraveller.gov.au/global-covid-19-health-advisory
I trust this information has been of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong(Petition No. EN2695)
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for the referral of petition EN2960 of 18 October 2021 requesting repatriation of Australian citizens stranded in Bangladesh during the pandemic.

The Albanese Government remains critical of the decisions made by the former government that caused so many Australians to be left stranded in precarious circumstances. Our view was that the former government should have done more to assist Australians overseas to return home.

A Senate Select Committee on Australia's response to the COVID-19 crisis found that the former government failed to establish stand-alone quarantine facilities, which resulted in overseas caps being imposed and restrictions on the number of Australians and permanent residents that could return home.
Since the 2022 election, all COVID-19 travel and border restrictions have been lifted, allowing Australian citizens, permanent residents and visa holders to travel to Australia unrestricted.

The Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) completed several audits on Australia's response to COVID-19 including in relation to the return of overseas Australias. Commonwealth agencies are implementing recommendations in response to the ANAO's COVID-19 audit program. DFAT's implementation of agreed recommendations will improve its crisis management framework and support data management processes to better assist Australians affected by crises overseas.

Australians seeking up-to-date travel advice on COVID-19 requirements overseas can refer to DFAT's Smartraveller website to access destination-specific information: https://www.smartraveller.gov.au/global-covid-19-health-advisory
I trust this information has been of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong(Petition No. EN2690)
COVID-19
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence regarding petition number EN3001. I apologise for the delay in responding and truly appreciate your interest in protecting the public, particularly those most vulnerable.
The National COVID-19 Health Management Plan (National Plan) outlines the current Australian Government health supports to manage COVID-19 over 2023.

The National Plan reflects a consistent approach across Australia, agreed by National Cabinet on 30 September 2022, to transition the COVID-19 response with a priority to minimise the incidence of death and severe illness, particularly focusing on those most at risk. The National Plan can be found at www.health.gov.au by searching for 'National COVID-19 Health Management Plan'.

Since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic in January 2020, the Government, through the National Medical Stockpile, has supported frontline health workers and Residential Aged Care Facilities, disability and First Nations people by providing rapid antigen tests, personal protective equipment including masks, and COVID-19 treatments to prevent the spread of, and treat those with COVID-19.
Providing access to free, safe and effective COVID-19 vaccines to everyone in Australia seeking to be vaccinated was and continues to be a priority of the Government.

Vaccination providers cannot charge to administer the COVID-19 vaccine; the vaccine and the consult appointment for patients remains free. The vaccines have been available through state and territory vaccination clinics, General Practices, Commonwealth Vaccine Clinics, Aged Care Facilities, Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Services and Community Pharmacies.

The Government continues to provide funding for the Vulnerable Vaccination Program which provides targeted initiatives for vaccinations for vulnerable and priority communities and those ineligible for Medicare. Primary Health Networks received funding from July 2021 and continue to receive funding for the Vulnerable Vaccination Program to sustain the priority of vaccinations for vulnerable people. This includes people experiencing homelessness, including those living on the streets, in emergency accommodations, boarding houses or between temporary shelters. To date, more than 111,600 vaccinations have been administered under the Vulnerable Vaccination Program, including more than 3,300 homebound vaccinations and over 600 non-Medicare vaccinations.

As Australia moves towards living with COVID-19, the National COVID-19 Community Protection Framework will help outline what public health measures states and territories might put in place to manage the COVID-19 pandemic. This Framework can be accessed at www.health.gov.au by searching 'Community Protection Framework'.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely

from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong(Petition No. EN3014)
Asylum Seekers
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to correspondence of 22 November 2022 to the former Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs enclosing Petition EN3265, with 898 signatures, concerning assistance for Mr Rohullah Hussaini's family who are in Afghanistan. I apologise for the delay in responding.
Due to privacy considerations, it would be inappropriate to provide you with any further details about the status of this matter.
I appreciate that there is concern for the safety of the applicants and the time taken to process their application.

The Department of Home Affairs has received and currently has on hand an unprecedented number of applications for Refugee and Humanitarian (Class XB) visas from Afghan nationals. The Australian Government continues to work to ensure each case is considered and that those at risk of harm who meet visa requirements are resettled to Australia as soon as possible.

Humanitarian visa processing is a complex process and will take some time. Processing times can also vary according to the particular circumstances of the applicant, their location (be it inside or outside their home country), and their ability to travel, provide documents or access Australian Government officials.
The Department will make contact with the applicant or the authorised recipient should further information be required or when the application is finalised.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3265 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles(Petition No. EN3014)
Asylum Seekers
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to correspondence of 22 November 2021, to the former Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, enclosing Petition EN3462 with 282 signatures, concerning the Murugappan family. I apologise for the delay in responding.

As a signatory to the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees and its 1967 Protocol (the Refugee Convention), I can assure you that Australia takes its international obligations seriously and provides protection to refugees consistent with the obligations set out in the Refugee Convention, and other relevant international treaties to which Australia is a party. Unlawful non-citizens are only removed if the Australian Government is satisfied they do not engage Australia's non-refoulement obligations and that removal would not breach Australia's international obligations.

Home Affairs Portfolio Ministers have personal intervention powers under the Migration Act 1958 (the Act) that allow them to grant a visa to a person, if they think it is in the public interest to do so. The public interest powers are non-compellable, that is, the Ministers are not required to exercise these powers. It is for the Ministers to define what is in the public interest.
On 5 August 2022, I exercised my non-compellable power under section 195A of the Act to grant Former Resident (subclass 151) visas to all four members of the family.
The Murugappan family have no further matters before the Department. Thank you for bringing Petition EN3462 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles(Petition No. EN3462)
Gambling
Dear Chair

I refer to the email of 14 February 2022 f om the former Chair of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions, Mr Ken O'Dowd MP, to the former Minister for Communications, the Hon Paul Fletcher MP, regarding Petition EN3559. I am responding to this petition as the current Minister for Communications in this term of Govenm1ent. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The signatories of this petition have expressed concern regarding the levels of gambling losses and harm experienced by Australians and are calling for the House of Representatives to ban gambling advertising on all Australian media.

The Government recognises the importance of gambling promotions being presented in a responsible manner. Advertising regulation in Australia is intended to strike a balance between legitimate commercial interests and appropriate community safeguards.

The Government is committed to guaranteeing online gambling takes place under a robust legislative framework with strong consumer protections, including through the continued implementation of the National Consumer Protection Framework for Online Wagering.

A key part of the Framework is consistent gambling messaging, which requires gambling providers to use the same messaging about the risks and potential harm of gambling in all advertisements. These new taglines will be implemented across all platforms by 30 March 2023. Further information on the new gambling messages can be found at dss.gov.au/communities-and-vulnerable-people-programs-services-gambling/information-for-online-wagering-providers.

Another part of the Framework is BetStop, a national self-exclusion register for online wagering, which is expected to launch in early 2023. If an individual self-excludes using the register, wagering providers will be required to close all betting accounts and must not let the individual place a bet, open a new account, or send them marketing messages. More information on BetStop can be found at acma.gov.au/betstop-national-self-exclusion-register.

On 15 September 2022, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Social Policy and Legal Affairs launched an inquiry into online gambling and its impacts on those experiencing gambling harm. The inquiry will include examining the effectiveness of current gambling advertising restrictions on limiting children's exposure to gambling products and services, including consideration of the impact of advertising through social media, sponsorship or branding from online licensed gambling operators. The Co1mnittee sought submissions from the public by 11 November 2022. The Government will consider the Committee's recommendations when it releases its final report. More information about the inqui1y can be found at aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/House/Social_Policy_and_Legal_Affairs/Onlinegamblingimpacts.
I have enclosed some additional information regarding the current gambling advertising restrictions.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I trust the information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland(Petition No. EN3559)
Media
Dear Chair

I refer to the email of 14 February 2022 from the former Chair of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions, Mr Ken O'Dowd MP, to the former Minister for Communications, the Hon Paul Fletcher MP, regarding Petition EN3767. I am responding to this petition as the current Minister for Communications in this term of Government. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The signatories of this petition have expressed concern regarding the publication and broadcast of photographs of victims, particularly children, in news media. The petition is calling for the House of Representatives to introduce a law where pictures of children involved in an accident, particularly at the scene of the accident, are not allowed to be shown in news media except with the express written consent of their parent or legal guardian.
The Australian Government believes that a balanced, robust and independent media sector plays an important role in Australia.

Where media services are regulated in Australia, the framework they are subject to depends on the platform on which they are provided. The importance of a free media is recognised under these frameworks through an emphasis on industry playing a leading role in the development and administration of content regulation.

Provided broadcasters and publishers meet their regulatory obligations, the selection of images shown alongside news stories is an editorial decision for each broadcaster and publisher and the Government does not seek to intervene in such decisions.

Most content broadcast in Australia is regulated by co-regulatory codes of practice developed by broadcasting industry sectors in accordance with the Broadcasting Services Act 1992. This co-regulatory system recognises the importance of television and radio content reflecting community standards. Codes of practice are available on the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) website at acma.gov.au/industry-codes-practice.

Generally, these codes seek to balance protections for audiences from potential harmful content while providing the opportunity for broadcasters to present newsworthy content in the public interest. However, the codes do not ban broadcasters from reporting certain news, nor do they seek to regulate the ways in which broadcasters report on or select stories.

It is, however, worth noting that broadcasting co-regulatory codes of practice are periodically reviewed. Members of the public may contact relevant peak industry bodies to raise their concerns, and to enquire about how they can contribute to future review processes.
Contact details for peak commercial and community broadcasting industry bodies as well as the two national broadcasters are provided below:
Free TV Australia (represents commercial TV providers)
Web: freetv.com.au
Commercial Radio Australia (represents commercial radio providers)
Web: commercialradio.com.au
Community Broadcasting Association of Australia (represents community radio providers)
Web: www.cbaa.org.au
Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC)
Phone: 13 99 94
Web: www.abc.net.au/contact/contactabc.htm.
Special Broadcasting Service (SBS)
Web: help.sbs.com.au/hc/articles/3600020111516
Australia's print news media operates under a self-regulatory framework, where the Australian Press Council (APC) assesses complaints for most industry participants.

The APC publishes a statement of principles which are binding on all publications subject to its jurisdiction which includes News Limited, Fairfax Media and most of the major news websites in addition to the principal union for employees in the media industry, the Media Ente11ainment and Arts Alliance. The principles are available at presscouncil.org.au/statements-of-principles/ and include a c01mnitment to accurate, fair and balanced reporting.
Complaints about content published by member organisations can be lodged directly with the APC in the first instance at: www.presscouncil.org.au/complaints/make-a-complaint/.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I trust the information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland(Petition No. EN3767)
Australian Public Service
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to correspondence of 12 January 2023, received from the Committee Secretary for the Standing Committee on Petitions and originally directed to the Minister for Women, Minister for Finance and Minister for the Public Service, Senator the Hon Katy Gallagher, concerning the working environment of employees of Services Australia (the Agency). Your correspondence has been referred to me as this matter falls within my area of responsibility.

The Agency employs about 31,000 Australian public servants, who provide government services so people can get on with their lives. The Agency aims to provide services in a simple, helpful, respectful and transparent way. The Agency's services support Australians who are vulnerable or who are experiencing times of crisis or life-changing circumstances.

The Agency has established processes to support staff who want to raise concerns or complaints about inappropriate behaviour in their workplaces, or to seek review of management decisions. These processes include a dedicated Respect team, which provides a human-centred approach to ensure staff can feel safe and heard when raising concerns about inappropriate behaviour such as bullying, harassment and sexual harassment.

The Respect team directly helps staff resolve more than 90 per cent of the issues raised, within the first day or so from initial contact. Where there are a number of issues raised by staff in the same workplace, the Respect team may refer to the Agency's People Solutions Branch, which undertakes an appropriate organisational health intervention. Some matters are referred to the Conduct Standards team for investigation undertaken by trained staff or external workplace investigators, in accordance with procedures established by the Australian Public Service Commission. Appropriate disciplinary action is taken if a breach of the Australian Public Service (APS) Code of Conduct is proven. Sanctions imposed may include termination, suspension, reduction in classification or salary, or a financial penalty.

The Respect team also provides a Staff Family and Domestic Violence service to support affected staff, provide advice on leave and support services that can be accessed and assist relocation of the staff member and family, where necessary. The Agency has also contracted an independent Employee Assistance Provider, through which staff, contractors and their families can access confidential counselling, psychological and financial advisory services.

Staff can also raise issues through their managers, Health and Safety Representatives, Harassment Contact Officers, union representatives or officials, and have access to authorities and tribunals including the APS Merit Protection Commission, Australian Human Rights Commission, Comcare, Administrative Appeals Tribunal, Commonwealth Ombudsman and Fair Work Commission.

It is disappointing that some employees feel their psychological wellbeing is not supported by their working environment, and that it is necessary to approach their Member of Parliament. Services Australia, its executives and employees are subject to parliamentary oversight and APS processes, and employees have multiple processes and external jurisdictions to raise these issues.
I trust this information is of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Government Services, Mr Shorten (Petition No. 3925)
Pensions and Benefits
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 27 September 2022 about petition EN3957, which requests an annual evaluation of government payments, including JobSeeker and Commonwealth Rent Assistance. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Government recognises that living on income support payments can be challenging, and it is important that payment rates keep up with the cost of living. To address the effects of inflation, payments such JobSeeker and pensions are increased twice a year in March and

September. JobSeeker is indexed in line with the Consumer Price Index (CPI), while pensions—including the Age Pension—are indexed to the higher of the increase in CPI and the Pensioner and Beneficiary Living Cost Index (PBLCI). Pensions are then benchmarked to Male Total Average Weekly Earnings (MTAWE) to ensure they keep pace with community living standards.
Other allowances, such as Youth Allowance, are indexed each year in January to CPI.

In September 2022, the Government oversaw the largest indexation increase to pensions and allowances in over a decade. For example, the basic rate of JobSeeker for a single person with no dependents increased by $25.70 a fortnight. In January 2023, around one million young people, carers and students received an increase to their income support payments. This was the largest indexation increase to Youth Allowance since the payment was introduced in 1998.

Commonwealth Rent Assistance (CRA) is available to help eligible income support recipients with the costs of renting in the private market. It is also indexed twice a year in March and September, in line with CPI, to keep pace with changes in cost of living.

As you may be aware, in December 2022 the Treasurer, the Hon Dr Jim Chalmers MP and I established an expert Economic Inclusion Advisory Committee. We have tasked the Committee to provide advice to Government on boosting economic inclusion and tackling entrenched disadvantage, including the adequacy and sustainability of income support payments ahead of every Federal Budget.

The Government is committed to formally legislating the role of the Committee, and undertaking statutory appointments, in 2023. For further information on the Committee, including its membership, see ministers.dss.gov.au/media-releases/9926.

In addition to CRA, the Government has a range of policies to support access to housing, align the efforts of the Commonwealth and state and territory Governments to deliver better housing outcomes and increase housing supply and affordability for renters and buyers across Australia.

In 2022-23, the Government expects to spend around $7.2 billion to help improve housing and homelessness outcomes. This includes an expected $5.1 billion in Commonwealth Rent Assistance to help eligible households receiving income support to pay their rent, and around $1.6 billion through the National Housing and Homelessness Agreement to support state and territory governments to deliver housing and homelessness services and programs.
I appreciate you bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth(Petition No. EN3957)
Migration
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 27 September 2022 enclosing petition EN3960, with three signatures, concerning Parent visas. I apologise for the delayed response.

Family migration is an important element of Australia's migration system, allowing Australian citizens and permanent residents to reunite with their family members and contribute to stronger social cohesion outcomes. It is recognised that immigrant parents can make valuable social contributions to their families and local communities.

It has been the long-standing practice of successive governments to manage the orderly delivery of Migration Program outcomes against planning levels. The Australian Government sets the size and composition of the Migration Program each year through the Government's Budget process following consultations with state and territory governments, business and community groups and the wider public.

Following the public consultations, the permanent Migration Program is set with Australia's immediate and longer-term economic and social needs in mind. Immigration policy has enduring effects on many dimensions of Australian life. Getting the policy settings right is critical to maximising community wellbeing, and the relative merits of any policy needs to be assessed against a broader context that takes into account all the relevant dimensions of societal wellbeing.

Processing times for Parent visas are impacted by a range of factors, including the number of places the Government allocates to a program each year, and the level of demand for each visa category. High volumes of Parent visa application lodgements, which for a number of years exceeded annual migration planning levels set by successive Governments, have resulted in extended processing times.

Additionally, the COVID-19 pandemic significantly affected the availability of key assessment services (such as medical checks). This impacted applicants' ability to meet visa criteria, and disrupted the Department of Home Affairs' visa processing services.

The time taken to process visa applications can also vary according to the individual circumstances of each case. The quality and completeness of applications, applicants' responsiveness to requests for information, and the complexity often involved in assessing character, health and security requirements, can influence processing times. The processing of Family visa application backlogs, particularly in the Parent program, remains a priority for the Government.

Reducing the Parent visa backlog is a complex issue and will require a number of strategies to be successful. The lengthy processing times for Parent visas was one of the key issues raised in public submissions to the 2021-22 Senate inquiry into the 'Efficacy, fairness, timeliness and costs of the processing and granting of visa classes which provide for or allow for family and partner reunions'.

Among a range of other strategies under consideration, the Government has recognised the impact of the above factors on processing times and in the October 2022 Budget announced an increase in the migration planning level for Parent visas from 4,500 in 2021-22 to 8,500 places in 2022-23.

On 2 September 2022, the Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Cyber Security, the Hon Clare O'Neil MP, announced a comprehensive review of the purpose, structure and objectives of Australia's migration system to ensure it meets the challenges of the coming decade. Further information on the review can be found on the Department's website at: https://www.homeaffairs.gov.au/help-and-support/how-to-engage-us/consultations/australias-22-23-migration-program. The future direction of the Family visa program, including Parent visas, will be informed as part of this review.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3960 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles(Petition No. EN3960)
Ukraine
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 27 September 2022 enclosing Petition EN4031, with 19 signatures, concerning the cancellation of visas for Russian Duma members. I apologise for the delay in responding.
The Australian Government continues to protect the Australian community from the risk of harm posed by non-citizens who engage in criminal conduct or behavior of concern.

Most permanent and temporary visas are subject to Public Interest Criterion (PIC) 4003(a) in the Migration Regulations 1994, which states that a visa held by a person whose presence in Australia is, or would be contrary to Australia's foreign policy interests, may be cancelled. Any cancellation would be dependent upon the Foreign Minister making a determination under this public interest criterion.

Australia has implemented a comprehensive suite of measures to maintain pressure on Russia. Australia has imposed targeted financial sanctions and travel bans on 416 members of the Russia State Duma and 144 senators of the Russian Federation Council. Travel bans prohibit the entry into or transit through Australia of designated persons. A person subject to a travel ban may be a citizen or resident of any country. Further sanctions remain under active consideration.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4031 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles(Petition No. EN4031)
Media
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 27 September 2022 regarding Petition EN4036. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The signatories of this petition have expressed concern regarding the use of sirens and similar sounds in advertisements on radio and is calling for the House of Representatives to ban the use of such sounds.

Most content broadcast in Australia is regulated by co-regulat01y codes of practice developed by broadcasting industry sectors in accordance with the Broadcasting Services Act 1992. This co-regulatory system recognises the imp01tance of television and radio content reflecting community standards. Codes of practice are available on the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) website at acma.gov.au/indust1y-codes-practice.

Provided radio broadcasters meet their regulatory obligations, the selection of sounds used in advertisements is an editorial decision for each broadcaster and the Government does not seek to intervene in such decisions.

The Commercial Radio Code of Practice, which applies to all commercial radio broadcasters, includes provisions relating to material that is not suitable for broadcast. This does not currently restrict the use of sirens or similar sounds.

It is worth noting, however, that broadcasting co-regulatory codes of practice are periodically reviewed. Members of the public may contact relevant peak industry bodies to raise their concerns, and to enquire about how they can contribute to future review processes.
Contact details for peak radio broadcasting industry bodies are below:
Commercial Radio Australia (represents commercial radio broadcasters)
Web: commercialradio.com.au
Community Broadcasting Association of Australia (represents community radio broadcasters)
Web: www.cbaa.org.au

Additionally, the content of advertisements is required to comply with the self-regulatory codes of practice developed by the Australian Association of National Advertisers (AANA), including the AANA Code of Ethics. These advertising Codes are platform neutral (including broadcast platforms, outdoor media and social media) and adapt to keep pace with changing consumer expectations. These codes can be found on the Ad Standards website at www.adstandards.com.au.

The AANA Code of Ethics contains a range of provisions relating to taste and decency, including requirements that advertising or marketing communication shall not depict material contrary to prevailing community standards on health and safety.

Complaints about the content of advertisements can be directed in writing to Ad Standards for consideration by the Ad Standards Community Panel. Complaints can be lodged through the Ad Standards website at www.adstandards.com.au/lodge-complaint.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I trust the information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland(Petition No. EN4036)
Rural and Regional Radio
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 27 September 2022 regarding Petition EN4049. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The signatories of this petition have expressed concern regarding interference on the 87.6MHz frequency in the Ballarat licence area. The petition is calling for the House of Representatives to make available FM frequencies 97.6MHz and 95.9MHz for allocation to other broadcasters, preferably to PHAZE Broadcasting Pty Ltd.

Under the Radiocommunications Act 1992 and the Broadcasting Services Act 1992, the Australian C01mnunications and Media Authority (ACMA) is responsible for planning and allocating radio frequency spectrum to radio broadcasting services. ACMA issued the Broadcasting Services (Availability of Spectrum—Open Narrowcasting Services) Determination 2022 to make part of the FM spectrum range (87.5 MHz to 88.0 MHz) available for allocation of low power open narrowcast (LPON) transmitter licences until 31 December 2035.

LPON services are limited in a number of ways, as reflected in their licence conditions and this can include narrow content or limited coverage. These services do not have any guarantee of spectrum and if they cause interference to other radio services, ACMA can cancel their licence. This is one the reasons why LPON licences are not as costly and have a much lighter regulatory regime that other radio services.

ACMA established the LPON sub-band to provide scope for LPON operators while also protecting the interference regimes of the existing national, commercial and co1mnunity radio services within each licence area. It is an ACMA decision on whether there are available frequencies within a licence area and a key consideration is interference. LPON services would not be moved to frequencies outside the sub-band and planning for any other FM frequencies within Ballarat licence area would require significant technical planning work by ACMA. As such, LPON services in the Ballarat region are limited to FM centre frequencies 87.6 MHz, 87.8 MHz and 88.0 MHz and any other frequencies if identified would be allocated according to the appropriate radio process.
ACMA has been working with PHAZE FM on this issue for some time and has been investigating inference claims and licence condition compliance.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I trust the information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland(Petition No. EN4049)
Immigration Detention
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 to the Minister for Home Affairs, the Hon Clare O'Neil MP, enclosing Petition EN4186 with three signatures, concerning availability of computers to the detainees at the Melbourne Immigration Transit Accommodation (MITA). Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

The Department of Home Affairs and the Australian Border Force (ABF) invests a significant amount of resources to provide high quality facilities, amenities, and a broad range of services, and activities to ensure the health and wellbeing of detainees and safety and security within its immigration detention facilities (IDFs).

The Department and the ABF provide computers with internet access, scanners and printers to all detainees. Facilities allow detainees access to personal email accounts, word processing, spreadsheets and internet browsing. Detainees are also able to use their personal devices to access the internet.
If the Facilities and Detainee Service Provider (FDSP) receives a complaint relating to a computer at the MITA not working, technicians are engaged and issues are rectified as soon as practicable.
The FDSP continues to ensure currency and effectiveness of computer systems at all IDFs and engages with detainees to ensure the performance of computers delivers a suitable end user experience.

The FDSP has a complaints management system in place to manage complaints from detainees. All detainees are able to lodge a complaint or provide feedback on any aspect of their immigration detention without hindrance or fear of reprisal. Any detainee who is not competent in the English language is entitled to interpreter services for all formal correspondence, which includes complaints.

Detainees are encouraged to contact the Global Feedback Unit within the Department at: https://www.homeaffairs.gov.au/feedback. Providing feedback this way ensures that feedback and/or concerns are actioned appropriately, including formal registration, acknowledgment and allocation to the responsible business area for actioning if required.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4186 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles(Petition No. EN4146)
Immigration Detention
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 to the Hon Clare O'Neil MP, Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Cyber Security, enclosing Petition EN4187, with three signatures, concerning smoking within immigration detention facilities (IDFs). Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

There are strict rules in place allowing immigration detainees to smoke in outdoor smoking areas. Within each IDF, there is signage indicating authorised smoking areas. An area without signage is a non-smoking area.

The Australian Border Force (ABF) does not authorise the use of toasters for lighting cigarettes. Fixed electric lighters are in place in all designated outdoor smoking areas. There are measures in place to ensure that detainees only utilise the permitted smoking areas and fixed electric lighters. Facilities and Detainee Service Provider (FDSP) staff continually remind detainees to smoke in designated smoking areas and utilise the provided fixed lighters.

The ABF has reviewed your allegation in conjunction with the FDSP and can advise that there is no evidence to suggest FDSP staff are promoting or condoning the misuse of electrical appliances or smoking outside the designated smoking areas.

All personnel working in an IDF must abide by a code of conduct. Allegations of staff involving serious misconduct are referred to the Department of Home Affairs' Integrity and Professional Standards area for further investigation.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4187 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles(Petition No. EN4187)
Helium Balloons
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4351—Prohibit the release of helium filled balloons and regulate the sale and use of helium to inflate balloons.

Management of waste is primarily the responsibility of state and territory governments, which regulate and manage waste in accordance with their respective legislation, policies and programs. The Australian Government notes that some jurisdictions have banned the release of balloons.

The Australian Government is responsible for national legislation, strategies and policy frameworks for waste, including measures that give effect to obligations under international agreements. The Government meets regularly with states and territories and continues to discuss priorities for phase out of single use plastics, but these are ultimately concerns for state and territory governments and their regulatory agencies.
Local governments have responsibility for waste management within their local areas as laid down by the regulatory framework of each state or territory.
Local and state governments may raise awareness of responsible waste disposal through information campaigns, in addition to regulations and processes used to minimise and manage waste.
It is the responsibility of every citizen, including businesses and community organisations, to minimise their impact on the environment and dispose of waste in a responsible manner.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury, Dr Leigh(Petition No. EN4351)
Defence Procurement
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 28 November 2022 regarding Petition Ministerial Referral (EN4515)—Rainbow Warrior. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The Royal Australian Navy's ship naming process is well established and places a strong emphasis on promoting links between the Navy and the Australian community, reflecting a uniquely Australian identity.

The Chief of Navy and I receive many requests to name new Royal Australian Navy vessels, normally after cities, towns and regions of Australia. This is a notable and pleasing demonstration of the great respect that communities, ex-service groups and individuals have for the Navy.

The Naval History Section at the Sea Power Centre -Australia, registers each request. Reviewing these numerous requests is an integral part of the naming process and I can assure you that all representations receive careful consideration. The process examines many aspects including history, community expectations and the need to balance representation from across Australia.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence, Mr Marles(Petition No. EN4515)
Human Rights: Iran
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 28 November 2022 concerning petition number EN4540, Hold IRGC accountable for the death of Mahsa Amini.

The Australian Government strongly condemns the ongoing and reprehensible actions of the Iranian regime. We have been active and consistent in publicly calling out Iran on its egregious behaviour and continue to advocate strongly in support of the human rights of the Iranian people. We have also imposed targeted sanctions on a number of Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) linked persons and entities.

I understand that those who are calling for the IRGC to be listed under the Criminal Code want the IRGC to face consequences for its actions. However, listing an organisation is not a foreign policy measure to increase pressure on foreign governments. The purpose of listings under the Criminal Code is to make it easier to prosecute individuals in Australia for supporting terrorist organisations. Under the Criminal Code, a terrorist organisation is a non-state actor that seeks to intimidate a government or the public to advance a political, religious or ideological cause through the use of violence. As an organ of a nation state, the IRGC is not the kind of entity that is covered by the terrorist organisation provisions in the Criminal Code.

I also note that listing an organisation as a terrorist organisation under the Criminal Code does not enliven new powers for the Australian Federal Police or the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, nor expand the range of offences that can be investigated by law enforcement.
I have copied this letter to Senator the Hon Penny Wong, Minister for Foreign Affairs, and the Hon Clare O'Neil MP, Minister for Home Affairs.
I trust this information is of assistance. Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus(Petition No. EN4540)
Waste Management and Recycling
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence to the Treasurer, the Hon Dr Jim Chalmers MP concerning Petition EN4545 on the consistent use of USB-C charging ports in portable consumer electronics. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

On 24 October 2022 the European Union mandated a common charging port for consumer electronics such as mobile phones, tablets and headphones. The change is expected to harmonise charging technology and to reduce electronic waste as a single charger will be used for multiple devices.

While the Australian Government currently does not have any plans to mandate the use of USB-C charging ports for these products, I note that the Minister for the Environment and Water, the Hon Tanya Plibersek MP, has established a Ministerial Advisory Group on the Circular Economy. One of the tasks of that group is to advise the Australian Government on how to best design out waste, which may include the merits of a mandatory USB-C standard. I intend to work with the Minister for the Environment and Water as the Australian Government works through the options in this area.

In addition to this, Australia may see the rollout of phones, tablets, and devices with a common charger without regulatory intervention as manufacturers change their product design to comply with international markets.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury, Dr Leigh (Petition No. EN4545)
Veterans
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 28 November 2022 regarding Petition EN4548 concerning the administration of the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits (DFRDB) scheme and commuted pensions available under that scheme.

The DFRDB scheme and commuted pensions available under that scheme were reviewed by the Commonwealth Ombudsman in 2019 and by the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Reference Committee in 2021.

The Commonwealth Ombudsman concluded that some DFRDB scheme members were led to believe incorrectly that their commuted pension would increase once they lived passed the life expectancy factors set out in the scheme. The Ombudsman found this amounted to defective administration by Defence.

As a consequence, the Secretary of Defence and Chief of the Defence Force issued an apology on 3 December 2019, which was published in the Ombudsman's report on 11 December 2019. This letter acknowledged and apologised for the confusion and emotional impact the incorrect information may have caused to veterans.

Members of the DFRDB scheme who believe they have suffered a financial detriment as a result of the provision of such erroneous information, are encouraged to lodge a claim under the Scheme for Compensation for Detriment caused by Defective Administration (CDDA scheme). Members can obtain a payment if they can show they are worse off as a consequence of such defective administration, as compared against if they had not elected to commute their pension.
